description: Continuous interviewer transcript test cases for detection accuracy testing. These simulate real interview audio streams with questions/imperatives embedded in natural speech.

testCases.description: Interview intro transitioning to first question
testCases.transcript: Okay great, thanks for joining us today. So, um, let me just pull up your resume here. Right, so I see you've been working with .NET for a few years now. What got you interested in software development in the first place?
Alright, moving on to the technical portion. What's your experience with dependency injection? And how do you typically structure your applications? Do you follow any specific architectural patterns?
Okay, that's interesting. Um, so, yeah. Tell me about a time when you had to debug a really tricky production issue. Like, walk me through your process.

testCases.description: Transitional speech with no actual questions
testCases.transcript: Right, okay. That makes sense. Let me just make a note here. So, moving on from that topic. I think we've covered the basics pretty well.

testCases.description: Setting up a coding challenge with imperative
testCases.transcript: Alright, so now we're going to do a quick coding exercise. Nothing too crazy. So, write a function that takes a list of integers and returns the two numbers that sum to a target value. You can use whatever language you're comfortable with.
So let's talk about system design. Imagine you're building a real-time chat application like Slack. How would you approach the architecture? What components would you need?
Um so like uh what would you say is your uh biggest weakness as a developer and um how are you working to improve on that

So I've been doing these interviews for about ten years now and I always find it interesting how different people approach problems. You know, some people are very methodical, others are more intuitive. Anyway, I'm curious, when you encounter a bug that you've never seen before, what's the first thing you do? Like, what's your mental model for approaching unknown problems?
Tell me about your experience working in agile teams. How do you handle disagreements with team members about technical decisions? Can you give me a specific example?
Hmm, okay. I'm not sure I fully understood that part. Can you elaborate on what you meant by eventual consistency? Like, how does that work in practice?

So we use Kubernetes here, and Docker obviously. Our deployment pipeline is pretty standard, GitHub Actions, that sort of thing. What's your experience with containerization? Have you worked with orchestration tools before?
Quick fire round. Tabs or spaces? Git rebase or merge? SQL or NoSQL? Monolith or microservices?
So you mentioned CQRS earlier. Explain how you would implement that pattern in a .NET application. What are the trade-offs?

Let's say you join a team and the codebase has zero tests, zero documentation, and the original developers have all left. What would be your approach to getting up to speed and starting to improve things?
Alright, I think that covers everything on my end. Let me check my notes here. Yeah, I think we're good. My colleague Sarah will be joining us in a moment for the next part.

testCases.description: C# tutorial video - Arrays part 1 - Can you store different types in an array
testCases.transcript: This is part one of C-Sharp interview questions video series. In this video, We'll answer this interview question. Can you store different types in an array in C sharp. If you're wondering why this video series, we will discuss all the possible C-Sharp interview questions in this series. So, let's answer this interview question. Can you store different types in an array in C sharp. And the answer is yes, if you create an object array. Let's understand that with an example. Here I have a console application. Now let's create an integer array. Now look at this. I can store an integer within this array, because that is an integer array. If I try to store a string, look at what is going to happen. We will get a compilation error. Look at that. We have an error cannot implicitly convert type string to int. So arrays are strongly typed. You can only store integer type within this array. But then if you want to store different data types, create an array of type object. Then look at this. I am able to store an integer. I am able to store a string. Because object type is the base type for all types in dot net. All types directly or indirectly inherit from object.

expectedDetections.textContains: store different types in an array

testCases.description: C# tutorial video - Jagged Arrays part 2
testCases.transcript: This is part 2 of C-Sharp interview questions video series. In this video we will answer this interview question, what is a jagged array. Let's understand this with an example. Let's say we have three employees. Mark, Matt, and John. Mark has three qualifications, bachelors, masters, and doctorate, whereas Matt has only one qualification, that is only a bachelors degree. John has bachelors and masters. Now here different employees have different number of qualifications. So, I want a data structure where I can store these varying number of qualifications. Jagged Array is one of the choices. Let's look at an example of using this jagged array. So first, let's create a jagged array. Now what is a jagged array? A jagged array is an array of arrays. Now look at this, qualifications are strings. So I'm going to create a string jagged array, meaning an array of string arrays.

testCases.description: C# tutorial video - Abstract Classes part 3
testCases.transcript: This is part three of C sharp interview questions video series. In this video, we will answer this interview question, why and when should we use an abstract class. This interview question could also be asked in a slightly different way, give an example of where we could use an abstract class. Interfaces and abstract classes are complex subjects. If we are able to answer the questions related to them properly in an interview, the interviewer may get a very good impression of you.
shouldNotDetect: This interview question could also be asked

testCases.transcript: This is part 4 of C-Sharp interview questions video series. In this video we will answer this interview question, what are the advantages of using interfaces. Before proceeding with this, I strongly recommend to watch these videos from the C-sharp tutorial. In part 30, we discussed the basics of interfaces. We discussed implicit and explicit interface implementation in part 31.
